header.topics: Description of what a careers’ dept. at a university does; complex life decisions for students; attitude of students; year in industry in various disciplines; research placements; overseas students; Literacy/Numeracy for employers; Civil Service tests. What to do now retired: art classes, school governor and tracing ancestry
header.activity: a recently retired university head of careers talking about her work

body.u: is it ah it's recording erm you said that you've just eh retired recently eh what did you retire from?
erm the where I was head of careers
mm mm
erm so
what kind of things? so can you tell us a bit about what your job involved

I mean in the last sort of ten eleven years that I was there I was actually managing people who were delivering the service erm although I did continue to see students myself eh about erm ten percent of my time erm I think probably it's more interesting to describe what a careers adviser does rather than what the person who manages them does erm so there's within universities of course university being free agents we're at liberty to kind of define the job how we want to but if erm I mean was the fourth university I'd been in so
wwhich were the other ones?

erm I started off eh at the beginning I was in at erm and then erm because basically I got married and my husband kept being moved around erm I was at what now is which at the time was and then I was at shortly before it became when it was which was sort of post having children when the children were small that was my sort of going back to work job part time

and then I went to erm I suppose when they were about six and seven so within the sort of erm if you like the the sort of common threads of the job within universities erm a careers adviser would be allocated to certain disciplines so they would have effectively a kind of portfolio of academic departments so erm for example at we had somebody who erm had been a biochemistry academic so he covered all science and engineering disciplines erm and within that element of the role erm you would erm develop good relationships with the head of department and with usually there would be a particular member of academic staff who would be responsible for things like erm erm supporting the student managing more sort of personal tutoring that goes on through which you would be able to get your services sort of advertised erm in some departments this is where the greatest variation is erm in some universities and in some departments within certain universities but not others there might be a careers module so some careers advisers would also be lecturers erm and some of ours did that in certain departments so in managements and in I can't remember the other department but that would be a taught module that they would mark and so on so that's a quite a different set of responsibilities really because effectively you're having to design a teaching package and so and the funding as a manager gets quite erm a lot more complicated if you're getting internal money from departments for buying out certain careers adviser time erm but the what careers advisers in all universities do would be to see students on an individual basis and to see and to see students on in a group basis so whereas you might if you've got erm a commitment a teaching commitment within the department you'd be slotted into the timetable we also ran erm a programme of erm group work sessions which students could book into erm completely independent of their department so we would cover erm a whole variety of things and that would be we'd we'd sort of debate what was necessary for the forthcoming year and look at movements in the market and what we might need to ensure they know about and erm look at erm how successful they'd been in previous year as to whether we repeated them but you'd always get the sort of four or five core bread and butter sort of topics which are about marketing yourself finding out about employers erm performing at interview passing selection tests erm networking creative job hunting all those sort of bout five or six sort of core eh sessions we would we would run anyway but there might be other things which we'd top it up with depending on perhaps you know if the market had slumped in one particular area or something we might run sessions on erm erm you know alternatives to or
so so did you see it as er your responsibility to guide them into what was out there jobwise?
erm yes thththe very frustrating thing for the majority of career services
is that it's quite rare for it to be compulsory for students to use the service
that's what I was going to ask
mm

so there is a huge amount of effort that goes into actually advertising it marketing it internally to students and selling them the benefits because we have plenty of data to show that if you use your career service you're going to do better
mm yeah yeah
but whether that's because the people who would do better tend to but I don't know erm but that's that's always sort of an issue erm
mm
and the other flip side of that issue is if they did all come there's no way we'd have enough resources to see them all
mm
so erm I mean the workload issue particularly on the one to one basis erm probably during my time quadrupled I would think
mm
and in addition to that when I first started which was probably thirty years ago we had an hour per student nowadays we have ten minutes
mm
what can you do in ten minutes?
so not o
well the doctor has to see you in three so what can you tell him in three minutes?
is it three?
yeah three minutes
three?
three minutes is the allotted time
no
yeah it is that's why 's left the practice she said three minutes they're supposed to
it was ten minutes when my daughter was a GP
well I mean you some people can be seen in three minutes can't they?
but yes it's yes absolutely but yo they can't predict what's going to walk in through the door
no they can't so they're actually anticipating
yes yes yes
and in what year did they mostly come and visit you?
too late
mm
erm probably that was one of the goals we always had was to gradually shift the percentage that left it until their final year to come erm and one of the benefits
did did you did you achieve that?

erm yeah it went down to we got it down to about sort of oh I think it's about fifty-five percent of students who came on a one to one basis for a final year and so forty-five percent were pre final year
mm

erm but final year is too late I mean the biggest and most complex decision is what do I want to do with my life and you can't decide that you can't steer them through a decision making process when the timetable for some of the major employers is the same as a UCAS timetable so they'd be needing to apply to the traditional big scale high flying employers have closing dates that start in October in some instances they have closing dates which actually started before the students came back
really?

so you know there was that that was a really hard hitting message that needed to be part of the marketing erm and you know we were sort of taking a bite out of it every year really erm but that sort of decision making process the other thing that's difficult to get across in a marketing sort of erm to successfully in marketing is that careers advisers have mechanisms for helping you make that decision that really difficult decision too many students the feedback is well I didn't come to see you because I don't know what I want to do no wrong way round
mm
mm

you come to see us mm right at the beginning if you don't know what you want to do that way we've got two years or so to help you plan find out meet people make decisions decide it's wrong go back to the beginning again
mm
work work through that erm and

how do you find over the years erm the characteristics of students you know are they? are they the same as ten years ago or are they erm you know more interested or lack of interest or erm very kind of friendly erm what's the respect between you two? and how have they changed over the time

mm I mean I think it's always been the best bit of the job with the students oon the whole are mostly really nice people and it's really fun actually working with them as far as their sort of focus and ability to sort of negotiate all these complex decisions is concerned erm you always get the whole range you always get the whole range you always get the people who are completely clueless and don't know where to start in the nicest possible way you know they sort of
mm

this is a bit scary I've never had to make my own decision before erm and at the opposite end of the scale you do get and I think the numbers of those has gone up and up and up really over the last ten years particularly that there is a there is a bigger proportion who actually are rather more clued up and understand rather more about what an employer would be looking for erm I mean the government has been pushing all these sorts of things like skills based stuff for years now erm you know most of them have had some sort of skills portfolio from when they were at school
mm
so those sorts of words have become common
and are they valuable because sometimes when you see your children doing them you think what a load of rubbish really

and the work experience sorts of episodes and things but were you involved at all with the industry in at university

they would do erm I mean there aren't degrees at that are actually erm you know actually playing sport there there you know the the erm there's a degree called sport and exercise science which is basically a science degree so they're learning about things like erm anatomy and respiration and erm diet for fitness and you know training regimes and all those sorts of things so they'd either do a research placement in something like perhaps one of the sports bodies or possibly the civil service used to take a lot of them because it's pertinent to research for servicemen under stress as well

and what about did you also help the overseas students?
mm their demands on us were absolutely huge overseas students are hugely hugely motivated and will take up every service you possibly can offer them
mm

erm it's the number of times the government's changed the regulations about ability to or you know legal situation as far as getting jobs are concerned it's just you know up and down every year really erm but yes in many ways it was they all want to work in the UK basically and erm even under the post study work visa which generated immense sort of optimism that they were automatically going to be able to get a job for two years af in the UK afterwards erm unfortunately it didn't make employers want them just because they were legally entitled to work it didn't sell them into a job you know an employee wants to take a graduate with a view to the long term they don't want to take somebody who's got to go home after two years
yeah yeah yeah
erm
but although legally they're not supposed to
legally there's a there's a clash between the law in terms of equal opportunities and that was
yeah mm mm

I mean one of the things I didn't say was that careers advisers have a sort of responsibility to keep up to date with all those sorts of things so maybe shooting off to see sort of employers probably on average they do I don't know for the whole team we probably did about forty or fifty employer visits a year so then we'd sort of cascade it to other people erm and some of those and in addition to that there would be sort of regular training days on things like updates for post study work visas and those kinds of things erm and there's a very very strong national organisation amongst the university careers advisers far stronger than any of the other professional groupings because erm going back sort of thirty thirty-five years or so when it all sort of started to kick off there was an absolute dearth of information that students could look at on what it's like to be a logistics manager on a wet Thursday afternoon in February what would you actually be doing? erm and so nationally erm people did job studies and we all compiled them into a central sort of well nowadays obviously it's a database erm and they're all updated every three years so your young careers adviser or your recently appointed careers adviser would have sort of portfolio of you know you're going to have to do three job studies or whatever as part of your induction and eh and that's you know it's part of a sort of national commitment to keeping the kind of u expertise up to date and things as well and it also is brilliant for students you know so all the universities even though it's sometimes difficult within your university to get the university to relax their copyright but we had to all do that battle and persuade our university that for these particular pieces of work please let us release the copyright you know because the value of it is only if we all do it nationally and the whole thing is you know
mm
seven or eight hundred or so erm probably more than that now probably a thousand erm job profiles you know there's no value in having six that your university does
mm
erm
did you ever place anyone er overseas?
erm yes I would sort of the terminology isn't quite what we'd use when you said place
well no I mean for placement for a for a year's perhaps erm
but but oh yes I mean all the all the language students erm
would go
yes
what the Erasmus and perhaps?
and erm yes a lot of them did teaching teaching English for a year

or they could do an industrial or commercial placement but the numbers of those were quite tiny because in other European countries as you will well know they don't have this culture of any discipline you know you can't become very easily a an accountant or a marketing person or something if you've got a degree in a somebody else's language you know you need in it's much more common in other European countries to have the relevant degree to go into the relevant job but we've got this I think tradition that probably goes back to fourteen hundred you know when the only degrees you could do were classics or theology
mm

erm and so we have this long term sort of tradition that a graduate here when they're taken on is a trainee erm in most areas they're trainees whereas if you graduated in Germany say you'd probably would be twenty-seven and you would have done probably five years worth of different chunks of placements and so on and you'd go into a proper job as it were with a certain level of responsibility
and you still have child benefit?

they were

but eh yes I I think you know when when membership of the EU first took off and erm our visits to employers became European so we all trundled off round and and visiting all these employers cos everybody thought oh they're all going to get jobs over here well I mean it didn't happen did it? cos the cultures and the education systems don't fit so erm ah you know we were there's there's a lot of them who want their first job abroad and by far and away you know if you want to go abroad at all costs then the easiest thing to get into is teaching English because you've got that's your skill that you can offer in many countries is you know highly desirable erm or erm it there were students we have a lot of international students as well who've got you know erm a cross between different nationalities and so on who've got their own networks and so on erm they also I think benefit by getting a masters level in the UK if they're wanting to go abroad because that four years would have been in France the minimum four years of HE and if you've done one of your years is a placement I don't think they really that's not really counted so just staying on and doing a masters is is the one thing that can help but erm there were I mean we used to have all the you know all the websites and things for getting a graduate job in all these countries but the the record of people actually succeeding in any area other than teaching would be pitiful absolutely pitiful
mm

and some students are so naïve about it you know I can remember students coming in and saying you know they wanted to work in Finland or something so I'd say oh yeah we can show you who the employers are and this is the employers students who said but I can't understand this

it's like okay well how are you going to get a job there if you can't speak Finnish? you thought this through properly?

yes college of higher education was quite common but the the tthe principle of I mean there's a lot of theories that we work to I s there's probably three or four different basic theories of careers guidance which is about how yo what is the theory behind how people get to a decision erm and erm you know there's a psychologically based theory which is theoretically what we'd all work to which is psychological basically which is saying that making the assumption that once you've got a certain academic achievement then it in effect gives you an independence so you can base a decision on your own skills your own values your own sets of interests and so I mean that was the the sort of core assumption that the majority of the career services would be based on but you had to be aware with students that you would also come across students who were going to be making a decision on another basis erm
for example
for example erm a sort of something that's ah sociologically based erm so they may feel they're erm erm you know there are family pressures
following family traditions
mm mm mm
yes yes yes
mm

erm or they can be economically based decisions which tends to be more common if you've got something like a recession and were certainly much more common in terms of people who perhaps haven't moved away from home or was very very common in years gone by you know basically if you lived in a Welsh valley and you were a lad yy the chances are you'd go down the pit because economically that's basically all there was
pit mm
erm so going theoretically anyway and very loosely speaking if you get a higher education you get lifted out of that

erm and then sort of thethere's another theory about erm can't remember what it was called now but it's about industry experience so making a decision this is where the placement model fits that students can you know if they taste something then they they they're they're involved in actually assessing as part of that they may not realise it but they are assessing themselves against that role

as they're doing it erm and so they're thinking do I feel comfortable with this? can I actually do it? is it making me want to get out of bed in the morning to come here? do I foresee actually coming back to that and you were saying how your daughter was very motivated af you know we used to get the reverse as well we used to get a queue of them
